Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock, my heart thumping faster. My volunteer shift started in twenty minutes, and I was the only one with the keys to open the community center. I knew people would already be waiting outside, some of them relying on the warm meal we served every Thursday. As I reached for my coat, I noticed my spouse sitting at the kitchen table, staring into their coffee, shoulders slumped. I hesitated. We’d promised to communicate openly, to share our worries instead of bottling them up. I remembered how I’d felt last week when they brushed off my concerns, and I didn’t want to do the same. But if I stayed to talk, I’d be late, and the people outside would be left in the cold, maybe thinking no one cared. My spouse looked up, eyes searching mine, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. I stood in the doorway, torn, the keys cold in my hand, unsure which need was greater.
